text: - Hey, everybody, my name is Paul Roberts,
I'm the Director of Strategic Accounts,

and I'm coming to you from
Amazon's Generative AI Day.

We have thousands of
Amazonians here today,

but we're going to have a
really interesting conversation
with our Senior Vice President

of the eCommerce
Foundation, Dave Treadwell.
- Sure, Paul.
So I view our team as kind of the layer

that supports all of eCommerce
that Amazon does above us.
Everything that is about buying products,
digital goods, et cetera.
So our primary goal is to support
all of that shopping and commerce,
and we're a layer on top of AWS.
So we're sort of in between those two,
being a demanding customer of AWS,
like many of your other customers
where we strictly use AWS interfaces,
just like all other customers do,

in order to support all
of Amazon's commerce.
- That's great.

I mean, the scale of
Amazon is just massive,

and, you know, we certainly
learn a lot from you all.
One of the businesses that's in your remit
that you didn't mention is Prime Air.
I'm personally really interested in.
There's a lot of innovation there.

Anything you wanted to
share about Prime Air

and some of the things
that you're focused on?

- Sure, Prime Air is our
drone delivery service,

and we've been working
on it for many years.

Recently, we've hit some
pretty exciting milestones.

We've started delivering
with the new MK30 drone
from two locations in the United States,
in College Station, Texas,
and just outside of Phoenix, Arizona.
And Phoenix is especially exciting

because it's a real
fulfillment center for Amazon.
So we have all the product selection

that will fit in a drone is
available by drone delivery.
We're doing a 60-minute delivery promise,
and, in fact, often we're delivering
in a lot less than 60 minutes.
We've had deliveries as fast as 25 minutes
between when a customer clicks Buy
and when it shows up in their backyard.

So we're starting to deliver
for real with Prime Air.
It's a very exciting program.

We think it's going to do
really well for our customers.
- That's so cool.

I recently spent time in one
of our fulfillment centers
just outside Seattle,
and I got to see some of the robots

and the technologies happening
within Amazon Robotics.

And, you know, I understand
that we have over 750,000 robots
that have been deployed in the fleet.
So now with drones

it's pretty incredible
with what we're doing.

So on that note, in
terms of like innovation,
you know, generative AI is something
that's on top of everybody's minds.

There's a lot of things
happening across Amazon.
And what are you seeing
from your perspective across the business?
- Well, generative AI
is becoming as core to what we do as code.
Basically, it's permeating everything

that happens throughout our
stores' technology businesses.

We're using it to improve
customer experiences directly.
Like the Rufus shopping assistant

that we've released to
many, many customers

allows you to ask queries,
get product information,

get suggestions on
different kinds of products,
types of products you can buy.
It's really pretty cool,

very interesting way to extend
your shopping experience.
We're also using generative AI
for many internally focused scenarios
to do things like to improve the quality
of data in our systems.
One great example is the Starfish program,
where we basically use generative AI

to make our detail
pages, the product pages,
with richer information,
to improve the titles,

to improve the language fluency
in the product descriptions.

It improves the
completeness of attributes,
the correctness of attributes.
We found it to be really amazing
in terms of quickly and easily being able
to improve our shopping experiences

by giving better information
about our products.

And then broadly we're
finding generative AI
to be very successful
for make us more efficient as a company,
for handling scenarios
that today take people a lot of time,
we can make them a lot more efficient
with use of generative AI.
And we're very excited about

what it's going to do for our
business and our customers
and allow us to ship lots of products
inexpensively for all of them.
- And that certainly resonates.
I mean, specifically on the last point,
I mean, augmenting human capabilities

with artificial intelligence
makes so much sense.
I wanted to tie, you know,
Starfish and Rufus together a little bit

because one of the things
that the business of Amazon

and AWS partner closely
on is around Prime Day.
And, you know, one of the things
I think is really notable with Rufus
is that, you know, the Rufus team
built their own large language model,
and they're using AWS silicon

to host, to actually do the
inferencing for those models.
And there was, you know,
over 80,000 accelerators that we're using.
So pretty amazing, really cool

to see that partnership
between the two businesses.
And of course, as you said,
it does make the buying experience
great for our end customers.
So really do appreciate that.
You know, the other question here is
that something comes up all the time
when I talk to customers,

and a lot of our customers
focus on developer productivity.
And, you know, we think about, you know,
coding assistance and other capabilities.
What's your approach or your thoughts

on like helping our Amazon
developers be more efficient?

Any thoughts there?
- Great call-out.
Improving the productivity of developers
is something that gen AI
is starting to do at a big scale already.

For example, we used the Q
code transform capability

to update an enormous
amount of our software code

to modern versions of the
Java Development Kit, the JDK.
We estimate that, across Amazon,

we saved over 4,000
person-years of effort.
- Wow.

- By just automatically
upgrading this code.
It's kind of grungy, hard work,
it's difficult to get right.
It doesn't feel very exciting
because at the back end of it,
all you're doing is using a newer JDK.
Which is good in the sense

that it's more efficient,
it reduces latencies,
so the new JDK is good.

But the process of changing
code to make use of it
is kind of grungy, not very fun work.
So generative AI through Q code transform
has been exceptionally compelling
for making that process really quite easy.

And as a result, we're
saving a ton of money,
running things more efficiently.

We've reduced latency
in a bunch of places.
But not just Q code transform,
we're starting to use Amazon Q Developer
at pretty big scale.

Our developers are starting
to see the benefits
of having that kind of coding assistant

that can fill a lot of the
gaps of areas where, you know,

just get code out quickly,
pull things together for you.
So Q as a coding assistant
has also been pretty compelling for us.
- You know, one of the people on my team,
they were actually using Q Developer,

and they were building some
tooling to enable migrations

and help actually copy service
quotas between regions,
which I know is pretty important
as we think about different projects
happening across Amazon.
So really incredible.
You know, I know with gen AI,

like it is a newer focus
area for businesses.
But it can't come at, you know,

it can't all be sunshine
and rainbows, you know?

Have there been any
learnings along the way

where you're saying, "You
know, maybe this is something
"that we can make more efficient"?
You know, anything that you think
that we should be focusing more on
from an industry perspective with gen AI?
- Well, one area in particular,
the space is moving so fast.

You know, the right FM today
may be a different FM tomorrow.
The right way to use it may change,
the right way to optimize your capacity

and your use of that can
change really quickly.

It's been one of the most
fast-moving technologies
I've experienced in my career.

And so in order to make
effective use of it,
retaining flexibility, you know,
resist taking too hard a dependency
on any layer of the stack.
Things like Bedrock really help there.

You know, by programming
directly to Bedrock and that API,
if a new model comes along

that has better traits for
your workload for some reason,

makes it relatively easy
to move to the new model.
So really retaining that flexibility
is a very important thing to do
as things are changing so fast.

- Yeah, I think that's
really great to call out.

I mean, you know, when the
gen AI boom kind of took off,
I think people were really thinking about,

is there going to be one
model that rules them all?
And the reality is that there's not.
You know, the Bedrock team,
you know, there's a statistic,
and it's basically, you know,

3% of all Bedrock customers
are using one model.
So, you know, it's really interesting.
So what that's saying is like
there isn't one model to rule them all

and there's going to be
multiple different variants.
And so we are absolutely seeing that.
So I think that is an excellent call-out.

- And it's different models
in many different attributes.
So there's the quality of the output.

Some models are better than
others at the quality of output.
Some have better latency characteristics.

Some have better cost and
performance characteristics.

And because things are
changing so quickly,
you know, the best latency model today,
in two months, a new one might come out
or a new version of one might come out

that would change to take
advantage of that instead.
So really retaining flexibility

is quite important in this
fast-moving landscape.
- That's great.

On the model side, you
know, I had a question.
I don't know how deep we can get into it.
But you also have a team that focuses,

your BDT team focuses on
data and data catalogs
and thinking about things
like data governance and data lineage.
And I know that is really important

because, as we start
building different models

like, you know, Rufus is
our own internal model,

how have you guided your
teams to think about data,
the governance side, the lineage,

being able to track who's
using it, the provenance piece?
Like any thoughts there?

- Well, one thing that we've
been spending a lot of time on

is making sure that the right
people and the right systems
have access to the right data.
You know, historically we took

a make-all-the-data-available-to-everybody
kind of approach.
Many years ago we did that.

And what we're learning is
you really got to be careful
about who can get what data.
Some of that's regulatory driven,

like the DMA controls how
different services and people
can have access to different data.
Some of it's just basic security measures.
So we've been spending a lot of time,

especially with the BDT
team that you mentioned,
making sure that we have good controls,
good governance on our data.

Using low-level AWS
capabilities like Lake Formation
has really helped us a ton on that.
- Yeah, no, that's great.
I mean, I know there's a huge partnership
between the two organizations
and lots of innovation happening there.
So I think it's really great.

- A good example of us being
demanding customers of AWS

and making the AWS
offerings hopefully better

for all AWS customers.
- Absolutely.
Okay, so I have two more questions,

and one's going to be related
to gen AI and one's not.
So on the gen AI front, what's next?
Where do you see things going for Amazon?

- You know, I don't
think that there will be
a sudden stepped function change.
I think gen AI is something
that we're going to embrace more and more
in all the things that we do.

We're going to find that it
improves our productivity

for our developers, for
other kinds of workers.
We're going to find that it improves
all the experiences that we're offering,
especially in the shopping areas
that I pay the most attention to.

I think that this steady
embrace of generative AI
is going to really be transformative

and make Amazon hopefully
an even better place to shop

for all our customers.
- Yeah, no, I love it.
And just the innovation that's happening
certainly with our ads ecosystem.

Now ads is doing your
text-to-image, text-to-video,

and there's even, you know,
sound generation models.

So really interesting
innovations happening.
- Yeah, content creation is a scenario
that gen AI is very effective for,

and I know that's helping
a lot of advertisers

create advertisements
that are more customized,

more personalized for the
people who might want that.
- And that helps, you know,

even when you know folks are
trying to generate things

on the Amazon store and for the
different description pages.
Okay, so my last question for you is,
when we think about all of Amazon,
you've been here for eight years,
we talked about the Prime Air program,

I recently got to spend some
time with our Kuiper business.
But when you look across all of Amazon,

are there any innovations
that you get really fired up
and really excited about
that, you know, really helps think about

and keep innovation on
the front of your mind?
- You know, one that I'm super excited
about us starting to use is Q Business.

The opportunity to use
a generative AI chatbot
with RAG on our internal data

so that it can answer
questions very smoothly
just using our internal data.
It's very compelling.
Like you can ask questions about

how our internal systems
work, some of our policies,
and it just kind of falls out.
And it's amazing how productive it is.
- Yeah.
- Once you start thinking about,

"Oh, I bet Q Business can
answer this question for me

"because it's got access to
all the Amazon internal data."
It's really quite remarkable
how productive it makes you
just as an information worker.
You don't have to go searching, you know,
using classic search mechanisms

and find 38 pages that
kind of has something to do
with the thing you're looking for
and read 25 of them

before you actually get
the answer you want.

Oftentimes, it just gives you
the answer in a few sentences.
It's really quite a remarkable capability
that I think is going to make Amazonians,

it is making Amazonians
a lot more effective.
- Yeah, huge plus one for me.
I think retrieval-augmented generation
of being able to like plug in
additional context into these models
so you can have a richer response.
Super valuable.
My team is using it as well.
We're seeing huge results.
So, look, I wanted to say
thank you very much for the time today.
It was a great conversation,

and thank you so much
for being with us today.
- Thanks for having me, Paul.
